III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical Assistance was provided in the maintenance of the building. There
are some broken glass panes that have been replaced with boards or

cardboard at this time and will need to be fixed to maintain compliance with
Rule 400.4407. Jacob unit was also lacking some cleanliness in the showers
and bathroom area, and this will need to be addressed.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency had two Corrective Action Plans (CAPS) to complete for this period
under review. The agency has completed basic foundational training for both of
their investigations. These investigations occurred in close proximity of each other
and when the agency initially opened. The agency has focused on relational
training and incorporating that into CPI. Staff are learning to be proactive rather
than reactive. Staff interviews demonstrate their awareness of treatment model
and importance of building relationships with youth.
Financial Overview
The agency has no financial concerns based upon their most current financial
audit in 2024. This consultant reviewed the documents.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
The agency is in compliance with PREA.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency as had 12 discharges since the opening of the facility. Seven of those
were planned. Two were placed elsewhere by their judge, one was hospitalized,
and two went truant. The agency is focusing on relationship building to help
decrease the truancy. The agency has hired middle management positions and
are almost fully staffed with direct care workers. Shift and team leaders help train
youth care workers. Their trainings have included “consistency, compassion, and
connectivity.” This creates a better environment for the youth and a better way for
staff to engage with the youth. The agency is modifying what supervision looks
like. On the floor, supervision will be completed and then discussed in supervision

meetings with the staff. The agency also completes quarterly reviews so that they
can maintain compliance with licensing rules and ensure quality of the program.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed were upbeat and enjoyed their role at the facility. The staff had
no concerns and were able to describe the treatment they are focused on with the
youth. Staff were pleased with the current direction of the agency.
Youth were content and did not address any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has some minor damage to their windows due to youth who have
destroyed property. An exit sign was out on the Jacob Hall as well. The Jacob unit
did have debris in the shower areas and bedroom areas were not as kept as the
other units. Outside of these areas, the agency is maintained well and does have
an inviting atmosphere. The youth bedrooms are inviting, and they are able to
decorate to their liking. Outside grounds are also well maintained.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes. It is recommended that the agency be issued a renewal of their regular
license.
